Playing around with textile

26 Nov 2011

To create HTML from markup we need two things.

  • A markup language
  • A convertor from the markup to HTML

Searching the net gives us:

  • textile: a simple formatting syntax.
  • markdown: both a simple formatting syntax and a tool to convert plain text to HTML
  • RedCloth: a Ruby module to convert textile text to HTML
  • kramdown: a Ruby library for parsing and converting a superset of Markdown.
  • rdiscount: a Ruby implementation of the Discount libary to parse Markdown syntax.
  • redcarpet: and yet another markdown parser.

This blog post was written in textile and it was rendered with RedCloth

Side note: when writing blog texts in emacs it is best to turn off Auto Fill Mode. Because it completely messes up the generated text.
